## Age Structure and Dependency Burden

::: {.align-center}
[Every country, in every stage of development, has a]{.h} [dependency burden]{.hp}
:::

::: {.incremental}
- [Definition:]{.h} The ratio of non-working aged individuals to working individuals
- In [Developed Nations]{.hp}, population growth has slowed. 
    - There is a [large dependency burden]{.h} due to the [large number of retirees]{.hp} relative to working age individuals
- In [Developing Nations]{.hi}, poopulation growth is usually high.
    - There is a [large dependency burden]{.h} due to the [large number of children]{.hi} relative to working age individuals
:::

## Consequences of High Fertility

The latest empirical research points out that high fertility is a concern with possible severe consequences

::: {.fragment}
- Fast population growth tends to lower per capita economic growth
- Increased poverty and inequality
- Reduced education
- Health outcomes (risky pregnancies and dangers in frequent births)
- Food shortages
- Environmental issues (increased pollution)
- International migration
:::
